(bitterly) You think they want "suspected  communists" entertaining the American  public with party propaganda like,  gosh I don't know, "Sand Pirates of  the Sahara?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about all that. You want to  do the right thing? Then defend your  name. If someone says something about  you that's untrue, you have to stand  up and say so. I know the law, and  the law's on your side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you, Delly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete smiles and puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll stand by me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss, and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a thick bank of coastal fog just down the road,  obscuring any view of the ocean a mile away. It's deadly  quiet as gas station owner RORY, late 60s, pulls up and p his Model A truck. He gets out, and an big old German  Shepherd, LOTTIE, jumps out of the truck bed. Rory moves to the door, and is about to put his key in th lock, when Lottie starts whining, looking toward the fog  bank and sniffing the air expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsit, girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops -- he hears something, too -- a LOW RUMBLE. Lott starts BARKING. The RUMBLE is getting LOUDER. Rory's gett worried. He looks at THE FOG BANK. It's starting to GLOW from within. Lottie's barking gets  LOUDER and angrier. Suddenly, a large black car punches o of the fog bank and tears down the road. It's followed by another, and another -- and perhaps a dozen more cars and trucks, all heading hell-bent-for-leather toward the town Rory moves toward Lottie, trying to quiet her as the cars fly past the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhh. I know, Lottie. This time, I  thought it was the Martians for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is bedlam, overflowing with REPORTERS, NEWSREEL CAMERA CREWS, PHOTOGRAPHERS, you name it. A RADIO CREW is broadcasting in front of Mabel's Diner. T REPORTER is on-the-air, hugging his microphone, speaking  above the din. Mabel stands next to him, his hand on her  shoulder. Bob Leffert stands nearby, grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here with Mabel Lanier, the owner  of the diner here on Commerce Street  where Appleton often took meals.  Mrs. Lanier, tell me, what are your  thoughts about having such a  celebrated suspected communist in  your midst all this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, its kinds hard to believe,  'cause Luke -- I mean Peter -- is  such a... I mean, since he's been  back, I've never seen the town so  happy and all. It's like he gave us  some... I don't know... some hope, I  guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What she's referring to folks, is  yet another bizarre twist in this  story. Not only is Appleton alive,  but he's been suffering from amnesia  and living here in Lawson, where,  due to a startling resemblance,  everyone in town for the last three  months has taken him for one of  Lawson's dead war heroes, Albert  Trumbo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a catch in her voice) Luke. We always called him Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel glances at Bob, who lowers his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is at the desk, staring into space. Adele leans agai the radiator behind him. The silence in the room is thick Across the desk from Pete sits Leo Kubelsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FBI can't arrest you, because  you haven't done anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's a relief. I understand  they usually don't let that stop  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However... you're gonna be subpoenaed  to testify before the Un-American  Activities Committee when they open  hearings in Los Angeles. Now, if you  play ball and tell them what they  want to hear, they'll clear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I won't be a communist anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it doesn't make any difference  that I'm not one now, and have never  been one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo stands and walks to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid, don't get philosophical with  me. This is a game, but it's not  your game. You play by their rules,  or they'll ruin you. And they have  the power to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't it bother anyone that this  is a perversion of democracy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo turns to her and smiles. His tone is charmingly matte of-factly, not condescending in the least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, don't kid yourself. We don't  have a "democracy" in this country.  The Declaration of Independence? The  Constitution? These are pieces of  paper with signatures on 'em. And  you know what a piece of paper with  a signature is? It's a contract. And  you know what a contract is? Something  that can be re-negotiated at any  time. It just so happens that the  House Un-American Activities Committee  is re-negotiating the contract this  time around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo takes out a cigarette, lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time, it might be the FBI. The  time after that, it might be the  President. But it'll always be  someone. Count on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the country Luke fought  for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lest we forget, Peter, your own  military career was somewhat less  illustrious than Luke's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wrong, Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, don't let that stop you all  of a sudden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo pulls a folded paper from his coat pocket and hands i to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. When you're called, read this  to them. Just tell the bastards what  they want to hear, and we can all  get on with our lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a knock at the door. Leo opens it. Standing there a small MAN wearing a serious suit and an even more serio fedora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Appleton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) You found him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man reaches into his breast pocket and withdraws a bl backed folded document, which he hands to Pete. As he doe a FLASH lights the room. At the door, a pair of PHOTOGRAPHERS and a NEWSREEL CAMER are jockeying for position. Pete rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Appleton, you are hereby  subpoenaed to appear as a witness  before a special session of the House  Committee on Un-American Activities.  You are to appear in Los Angeles,  California, at the Biltmore Hotel,  at the date and time specified herein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete takes the subpoena. There's an awkward moment, as th newsreel camera is still rolling. Pete cradles the subpoe like an Oscar statuette and smiles into the lens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("on") This is a great honor. I'll treasure  this always. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: THE SUBPOENA
dialogues.text: in a partially-packed suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is sitting in a chair, reading the statement Leo gav him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) "I, Peter Appleton, do hereby renounce  my membership in the American  Communist Party, and by way of purging  myself of my indiscretion, wish to  provide the following names of fellow  members to this committee, so that  those persons may have the opportunity  to do as I have done..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scans down the page. It's a long list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He HEARS a "meow!" And turns to look.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: is standing in the bedroom doorway. He folds up and pocke the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Tim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, Old Tim appears in the doorway, wringing knit cap in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I... Can I t-t-talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Come on in. I was just packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete stands, gestures Old Tim to the chair, as he sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll come back, you know. They'll  all c-c-come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The customers? I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will. They w-w-will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete turns to Old Tim, fixes him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim, I have to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause, as Pete gathers courage and tries to find the word

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... I'm not Luke. Luke is dead.  He died in the war. He's not coming  back, and I'm not him.  I don't even  belong here. This whole thing started  out as an accident, and that's all  it is. An accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name isn't Luke. It's Peter. Peter  Appleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Tim stands and looks askance at Pete. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you think I didn't kn-kn-know  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I thought you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know more than you give me c-c- credit, that's for sure.  Don't you  see, it don't m-m-matter who you  are? All that matters is what you g- g-gave us. And you can't take that  away now. You're wrong, Peter  Appleton. You do belong here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans down to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hafta give us back the B-B-Bijou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Tim straightens up, nods at Pete. Then, silently, he  picks up Cat and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Adele walk slowly down the platform toward the  waiting train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Except a chance in hell of  coming out of this intact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be fine. No matter what Leo  Kubelsky says, you've got a hundred  and seventy-five years of American  law on your side. Don't forget that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you were coming with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's gonna run the projector  until you get back? Mrs. Terwilliger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we could train Cat to run the  projector. You know, a system of  scratching posts, and gears, and  levers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both smile as the train's HORN blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Board!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete picks up his suitcase and they walk toward the passe compartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring along something to  read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele pulls a pocket-sized leather-bound book out of her  purse and hands it to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think so. Here. This is  mine, you can borrow it.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOK
dialogues.text: Well-worn and scuffed, nevertheless the title is clear: CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete looks at the book, then at Adele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly light reading, I know.  Believe it or not, I've read this  since high school, and it got me all  the way through law school. Besides,  there's something in there that'll  help you. You won't have to get very  far, it's near the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearly touched) Delly... thanks, thank you. I'll  take good care of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just remember two things. First, the  law is a living thing. It made us  free and it keeps us free. Sometimes  it gets twisted around by people for  their own purposes. Sometimes it  makes mistakes, sometimes big  mistakes.  But in the end, the law  prevails for the just. Sometimes, it  takes a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. What's the second thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks for a moment. She needs the right words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be here... if you come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train pulls out. Adele and Pete exchange waves as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The House Committee on Un-American Activities has effecti taken over the Grand Ballroom of this magnificent hotel, the joint is packed to the rafters. Members of the AUDIEN crane their necks to see out into the hallway, from where the witnesses will be entering. The COMMITTEE MEMBERS are seated at their dais, brightly by the dozens of newsreel and TV lights. Elvin Clyde is s at the far right. Dead center of the dais is the Chairman CONGRESSMAN T. JOHNSTON DOYLE of Wisconsin, a husky man i his late 50s. He SLAMS his gavel down several times and t room goes quiet -- the talking stops, and the cameras sta whirring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele's in a chair, eyes glues to the TV set. Mrs. Terwil and Old Tim sit on the couch, watching attentively. Doc Lardner's in a straight-backed chair at a jaunty angl to the set, holding the rabbit ears uncomfortably high al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's perfect, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The committee and the chamber will  come to order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner forces a smile at Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweating and wincing) This television's a grand little  invention, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agenda for this morning's special  session of the House Committee on Un- American Activities shows a number  of witnesses, and I'd like to admonish  those that are here to view the  testimony of our first witness to  keep order at all times, or this  chamber will be closed. I'm referring  especially to the ladies and gentlemen  of the press. I hope that's clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Doyle scans the room. He clearly means business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Peter Appleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes and cameras swing toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: ON PETE
dialogues.text: As he enters the chamber, dozens of FLASHBULBS fire as ev eye and every camera follows him silently to his seat. As sits, he glances behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Kubelsky is sitting in the front row of spectators. H smiles and nods at Pete. Pete doesn't acknowledge him, and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The witness will please stand and  raise his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete does as instructed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you swear that the testimony you  are about to give before this  committee of the United States House  of Representatives will be the truth,  the whole truth, and nothing but the  truth, so help you god?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be seated and state your full name  and place of residence for the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Kenneth Appleton. Hollywood,  California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chair notes that you are appearing  without the benefit of counsel today,  Mr. Appleton. We certainly hope this  means that you intend to be fully  forthcoming with this committee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint smile) I'll do my best, Mr. Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, we're informed that you have a  statement you'd like to read, is  that correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently) A statement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle and Clyde exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. A prepared statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... no. I don't have a statement  at this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete turns in his chair and winks at Leo. Leo rolls his e and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele breathes a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's doing very well, so  far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They haven't called out the dogs  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well then, the questions will  be asked by the Majority Counsel,  Mr. Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV shot swings to see Elvin Clyde. He puts on his gla and fixes Pete with an oily grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr. Chairman, and thank  you Mr. Appleton, for appearing today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton, you mention that your  home is Hollywood, California. But  isn't it true that for the last  several months, you've made your  home in a town called Lawson,  California?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, that is true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton, do you know an "Albert  Lucas Trumbo?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke Trumbo? We never met. But I'd  like to think I know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that because you were masquerading  as Luke Trumbo while you were in  Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clyde you're twisting things  around. I wasn't masquerading. Luke  Trumbo... Luke was a good man who  gave his life for his country. I  just... happen to look a little bit  like him.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to notes) Yes, I see that Private Trumbo was  reported missing in action and is  presumed dead. I also see that you  were posted stateside during the  war. Fort Dix?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure we're all glad to see  you came through it all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few spectators titter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel and Bob listen to the hearing on a radio in the pac diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I see that you've been running  a movie theater in Lawson called  "The Bijou," is that also true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. But I didn't go to Lawson  to run The Bijou, that was... that  was something that just happened.  You see, I was involved in an accident  in Lawson, and I spent some time  recovering there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde holds up copies of the Los Angeles Examiner and Los Angeles Times with Pete's picture on the front page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone who reads the newspaper is  quite familiar with your...  "accident," Mr. Appleton. An accident  which, conveniently, came hard upon  your dismissal from United Pictures.  Tell us, this "accident" of yours,  are we given to understand that it  affected your memory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is the state of your memory  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Pete smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, what was the question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience LAUGHS. Clyde nods at Pete, forces a tight s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We... appreciate... your little note  of levity, Mr. Appleton, but this is  a very serious matter, and it merits  your fullest attention. (back to business) That state of your memory now, Mr.  Appleton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery Wyatt listens to the hearing on a store radio. Spen comes around the paint aisle, wiping his hands on his apr He moves to the radio and listens solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, are you referring to the fact  that I was suffering from amnesia,  and I've since recovered my memory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) I'm interested in knowing if you  remember things you did in your past,  or if they've been conveniently  "blotted out" as a result of your  "accident."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Mr. Clyde, I remember everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Good. (holds up a piece of  paper) Now, I hold in my hand a photostatic  copy of the attendance roster for  the "Bread Instead of Bullets Club"  of the University of California, Los  Angeles, dated October 11, 1935. A  copy of this paper is before you,  Mr. Appleton. Do you recognize it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete looks on the table and finds the roster. He's surpri to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Referring to line thirty-seven of  the document, does your printed name  and signature appear there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton, please tell this  committee what was the nature and  purpose of the "Bread Instead of  Bullets Club?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clyde, do you want to know what  I knew then, or do you want to know  what I know now? They're two different  things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start with what you knew then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd direct the attention of  counsel and committee to line thirty- six of the document, and the name  printed and signed there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see it. For the record, it reads  "Lucille Angstrom." What's the point  of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's what I knew then. Or  who I knew, I should say. You see, I  was trying to court Miss Angstrom. I  went to the meeting to impress her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Are you asking this committee to  believe that you attended a meeting  of a communist party front  organization in order to impress a  girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slyly) Well, if you'd seen Miss Angstrom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience LAUGHS. Doyle BANGS his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked for the truth. That's the  truth. I had no idea what the meeting  was about. I just sat through it so  I could be near her. I'm sure even a  Majority Counsel like yourself is  familiar with the concept of  impressing a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience LAUGHS. Clyde shoots a look at Doyle, who BA his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chamber will come to order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde shuffles some papers and looks back at Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Appleton. That was  what you knew then. What do you know  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a deep breath) Well, I know that I lost my job  because of one meeting I went to  when I was a kid in college. I know  that I've been branded a communist,  which I'm not, but even if I was, it  shouldn't matter, or what do we have  a Bill Of Rights for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, the witness is being  non-responsive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few members of the audience APPLAUD. As Pete speaks, th numbers grow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passionately) I know that a lot of good, honest,  decent people, people that I consider  my true friends, feel betrayed by  me, not because of who and what I  am, but because of what you say I  am! I know that I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle BANGS his gavel several times. Pete stops and the r falls quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatically) Mr. Appleton, you will respond to  the questions of this committee  without elaboration or speechmaking,  or the chair will find you in Contempt  Of Congress. You will not be warned  again, is that clear? (he lets this sink  in, then) Continue, Mr. Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking down at his  desk) Mr. Appleton...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde takes a long pause for effect, then looks up at Pet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you now, or have you ever been,  a member of the communist party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up the roster) Are you refuting this evidence and  your previous testimony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not refuting anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet you're contradicting yourself.  You earlier testified that you  attended a meeting of a communist  party-run organization, yet you just  said, under oath, that you were not  now -- nor ever -- a member of the  communist party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a contradiction at all,  sir. I went to the meeting, but I  didn't go as a member.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, as what did you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Pete smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little hesitant to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The witness need not be hesitant to  say anything before this committee,  as long as it's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete shifts in his chair, then leans into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I went as... a horny young  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber erupts in LAUGHTER. Even the other COMMITTEE  MEMBERS are laughing, except Clyde and Doyle, who BANGS h gavel vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Eldridge and Daley Thornhill listen to the hearin on the radio. They are both laughing at Pete's last comme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, he don't wanna spar with these  boys. They'll eat him alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room settles. Doyle wags his finger accusingly at Pet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) Mr. Appleton, you are making light  of a legally constituted committee  of the United States Congress. Believe  you me, you do not want to incur our  wrath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter-of-factly) I'm sorry, sir, I have no intention  of making light of this committee.  And I have no intention of incurring  your wrath, Mr. Chairman. I have a  few friends who have already incurred  your wrath. They've sent me letters  from jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Mr. Chairman! Mr. Chairman, the  witness is making another speech. I  would ask that Mr. Appleton be  admonished...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferent) Mr. Appleton, there is no question  before you at this time, but I'm  sure Mr. Clyde has plenty more  prepared, and if you'd like to either  answer them or plead the Fifth  Amendment, we can at least get on  with the business of this committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele moves to within inches of the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them Pete. Tell them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrestling with this) Mr. Chairman, as I understand it,  the Fifth Amendment pertains to self- incrimination, and I can't incriminate  myself because I've done nothing  wrong. Besides, incrimination is why  you have Mr. Clyde working for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde is still protesting, but Doyle waves him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, Mr. Appleton, just what  is your intention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete's sweating under the lights. He's bluffed his last b and he's on the ropes. He reaches into his pocket... and  takes out the prepared statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... Mr. Chairman, I have a prepared  statement I'd like to read...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hand goes to her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Pete. No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Mr. Appleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly reading) "I, Peter Appleton, do hereby..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops suddenly. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton? Mr. Appleton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I need a drink of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete fills a glass from the pitcher. Nervously, he spills bit, and is splashes onto his coat. As some of the specta chuckle, Pete brushes the water off. He reaches into his  pocket, and pulls out Adele's copy of the constitution. T cover is wet. He wipes it off and sets it down on the tab He takes a sip of water. Looks at the book. Picks it up. Pete's terrified, but in control. He speaks slowly -- he' making this up and thinking it out as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman... there's... another  Amendment... that I'd like to invoke  at this time, but it's not the Fifth  Amendment. I wonder if you're familiar  with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton, you will...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the book and reads, tentatively at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Congress shall make no law respecting  an establishment of religion, or  prohibiting the free exercise thereof;  or abridging the freedom of speech,  or of the press; or the right of the  people peaceably to assemble, and to  petition the Government for a redress  of grievances."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Silence in the room.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: She's smiling at the TV. Her eyes are filled with tears.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: He looks up at Chairman Doyle. Now fully confident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the First Amendment, Mr.  Chairman. It's the backbone of this  nation. It's everything that gives  us the potential to be right and  good and just -- if only we'd live  up to that potential. It's what gives  me the right to sit in this chair  and say my piece before this committee  without fear. It's the most important  part of the contract that every  citizen has with this country. And  even though this contract... (he holds up the book) ...the Constitution and the Bill of  Rights -- even though they're just  pieces of paper with signatures on  them -- they're the only contracts  we have that are most definitely not  subject to renegotiation. Not by  you, Mr. Chairman, not by you, Mr.  Clyde, not by any member of this  committee -- or anyone else -- ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pin-drop silence in the room. Pete scans the faces of the panel.  All betray anger.

dialogues.speaker: ON LEO
dialogues.text: He can't help but smile and nod appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when you get right down to it,  that's really all I have to say to  this committee. Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, Pete closes the book, picks up the prepare statement, rips it up, pushes back his chair, stands and  walks toward the door. The cameras swing with him, and  FLASHBULBS fire like machine guns. Doyle BANGS his gavel  insistently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The witness will resume his seat!  Did you hear me?! You are not excused,  Mr. Appleton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, slowly, APPLAUSE builds in the chamber, reachin crescendo as Pete reaches the door and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman! Mr. Chairman...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pete exits the hotel, a DOZEN REPORTERS AND PHOTOGRAPH have him completely surrounded. FLASHBULBS pop. He's take aback, flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing Pete) There he is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete! Are you going back to writing  pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a commie, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the girl, Pete? You gonna  marry her? Is she coming to Hollywood,  or are you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, fellas, I don't have anything  to say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is trapped in the crowd, when he feels a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: spins him around, and pushes him through the crowd toward the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the curb is a black Cadillac limousine. Leo hauls open the back door and pushes Pete in, before climbing in hims The limo drives away, as the reporters give chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo and Pete sit side-by-side in silence for a moment. Le breaks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was quite a show you gave them  today. We shoulda sold tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sorry for what I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not, why should you be  sorry? You're the new Peter Appleton.  You exercised your rights as a solid  citizen, first amendment, freedom of  speech, all that. Very noble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in silence again for a moment until Leo reaches  into his pocket and withdraws a gold cigarette case, whic he opens and offers to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo takes one for himself and lights up. Pete takes off h hat and nervously scratches his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When'd you quit smoking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke didn't smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. But you're not Luke. You're  Peter Appleton, the picture writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Not any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, you were in there, you saw what  I did. You think they're gonna let  me write pictures? Hell, they're  probably gonna throw my ass in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, I don't even know if I want  to write anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snickering) What, you're going to go back to  that hick town and run the projector  and marry the doctor's daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before Pete can answer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, I'm an agent. I buy lunches  and get deals made for guys like  you. That's what I do. You're a  writer. You write pictures. That's  what you do. And trust me, you'll be  back doing it again tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid, you gave them what they wanted.  This committee, it feeds on names.  The more names, the better. But for  some high-profile witnesses, like  yourself, any name will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, I didn't give them the names. I  wouldn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, all of a sudden, "Lucille  Angstrom" isn't a name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete freezes. He slowly turns to Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warily) Her name was right there in front of  them. They gave it to me, I didn't  give it to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's not what they think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, she was... she was a girl I  knew in college...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should keep track of your old  school chums. Turns out she eventually  joined the communist party. (takes a puff) On top of which, she's Lucy Angstrom  Hirschfeld now, and she happens to  be a writer for "Studio One" on CBS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realization dawning) Oh god, oh, god, no, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, our lawyers had a talk with the  Committee's lawyers. That Elvin Clyde  fella won't be too happy about it,  but we cut a deal. They cleared you --  and they're gonna thank you publicly  for your testimony purging yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank me publicly? For what? For  ruining this woman's life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive) Climb down off your cross. They  already knew about her. (off his look) She was subpoenaed six months ago!  Who the hell do you think named you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is dumbstruck. He slumps in his seat, ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he couldn't be happier) All of which means... "Ashes To Ashes"  is gonna be made, and you've got  your job back. (takes a puff) Congratulations, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete's breathing shallowly, on the verge of tears or scre or both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo pulls up, and Leo opens the door. Pete vacantly  grabs his suitcase and gets out. Leo shuts the door and c after him, waving Pete's hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter! Your hat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete comes back and takes his hat. Leo grabs his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was lookin' out for you all the  time, kid. You did good. I'm real  proud of you. (to the driver) Okay, let's go. (to Pete) Get some rest, kid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the limo pulls away, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, revealing the Super, followed by a sullen Pete, carrying his suitcases and hat. He sets them down a goes to the coffee table, where his boxes of belongings f the studio have been gathering dust these last three mont

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a key) Here's a new key for ya. That Mr.  Kubelsky, he's got you paid up through  this month. You got one swell friend  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Super moves to the door and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to have you back, Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits as Pete reaches into one of the boxes and pulls the tin-toy fire truck. Distractedly, Pete puts the toy b in the box and replies too late:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets his suitcase down and takes off his coat. As he d Adele's copy of the Constitution slips out of his coat po and falls open to the floor. Pete picks it up and absently turns it over -- and the  inscription inside the front cover catches his eye: TO DELLY, THE GIRL WITH ALL THE ANSWERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete closes the book. He thinks for a moment, then glance over at the phone. He picks it up and dials "0."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Western Union, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our view of the moving train is from outside, as it speed up the spectacular coastline north of Santa Barbara. Look into one of the train's windows, we SEE Pete sitting, sta out at the passing scenery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Adele, on my way back to Lawson  STOP. That is, if they'll have me  STOP. Train arrives four p.m. STOP.  Hope you can be there STOP. Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is just pulling in to Lawson. As it SHUDDERS to halt, the door of the passenger compartment opens and Pet steps out -- looks -- and his jaw drops open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ENTIRE TOWN has turned out. They're all there, smilin broadly. A large, hand-lettered banner reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CHEER goes up from the crowd, breaking the silence. Pet descends from the train and moves into the throng. The fi two people he encounters are Bob Leffert and Mabel Lanier bob sticks out his good hand and Pete takes it, both smil as they shake hands vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke... um, I mean, Pete, if it  weren't for you, I wouldn't have had  the nerve to ask this fine woman to  marry me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel's mouth drops open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, congratulations! When'd you ask  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy moley! Just now! (to Bob) Yes, Bob! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mabel kisses Bob for all she's worth, Pete continues i the crowd, where he's kissed, embraced, patted on the bac

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: is at the back of the crowd, working her way to the front She rushes into Pete's arms, and they kiss. Another CHEER goes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you got the telegram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, I'm so sorry about what they  did to you. I didn't think you'd  come back, I thought you'd want to  write again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dell, I can't write unless I'm happy,  and I can't be happy unless I'm here --  and with you. (grabs her shoulders) This is me, Delly. Pete Appleton.  And I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tears in her eyes) And (hic!) I love you, Pete!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss again. Pete pulls away and looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) C'mon, Dell, we gotta go. Showtime  in fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train whistle BLOWS as it slowly pulls out of the sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Happily ever after" is a relative  term, folks. My world is much smaller  now, and my dreams are very different  than they were. But I have something  now that I never had before: I have  the magic. And it's for sale at the  Bijou, every day of the year. All  you need is the price of a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We BOOM UP to see Pete and Adele moving into and being  enveloped by the crowd. Spencer Wyatt's band is assembled in front of the depot  office, and they kick into some up-tempo boogie-woogie as move up and away -- still in the same shot -- moving over the town, settling down again to grab a shot of the Bijou marquee.  The neon chaser lights POP ON, illuminating the sign, which reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, the letters on the marquee START SHAKING. We BOOM U TO THE TOP OF THE THEATER, and the "BIJOU" sign... ...as the train RUMBLES BY behind the theater... ...and the "J" teeters loose and swings by a thread... ...and we IRIS DOWN ON IT AND... CUT TO BLACK.
